consolation: Sometimes we tend to give more meaning to other people's words and actions than they actually have. Mistakes at work are common and they don't define your value as a professional or a person. Remember your achievements and strengths that make you unique.
solutions: Try to separate constructive criticism from personal evaluations. Your boss may have simply pointed out a mistake, which is a normal part of the work process.
Think about past successes and achievements at work. This will help you see that one mistake doesn't make you a failure.
Work on strengthening your self-esteem. The higher your self-esteem, the less likely you are to perceive others' words as criticism of your personality.
distortion: Chosen due to generalizing one incident (mistake at work) to an overall personality assessment ("everyone thinks I'm a failure")
negativeThought: I feel that everyone around me thinks I'm a failure
adaptiveResponse: One mistake at work doesn't define me as a professional or a person. It's important to learn from mistakes and remember your successes and qualities.
